## assertHttpStatus() function

Assert that an HTTP response finished with the given status code.

<b>Signature:</b>

```typescript
export declare function assertHttpStatus(response: any, expectedStatus?: number, { message }?: {
    message?: undefined;
}): Promise<any>;
```

## Parameters

|  Parameter | Type | Description |
|  --- | --- | --- |
|  response | any | HTTP fetch response object, as gotten from <code>await </code>\[\["net\_utils".fetch\|<code>netutils.fetch</code>\]\]<code>(...)</code>, or the promise resolving to that (e.g. just <code>[[&quot;net_utils&quot;.fetch&#124;</code>netutils.fetch<code>]]</code>(...)<!-- -->\`<!-- -->). |
|  expectedStatus | number | The expected HTTP status (e.g. 201 for Created) |
|  { message } | { message?: undefined; } |  |

<b>Returns:</b>

Promise&lt;any&gt;

{<!-- -->\*<!-- -->} The fetch response object.

## Example


```javascript
const response = await fetch(config, 'https://foo.example/');
await assertHttpStatus(response, 200);
// Or, the shorter form:
const shortResponse = await assertHttpStatus(fetch(config, 'https://foo.example/'));

```
